intro: Galium jordanii var. timeroyi, commonly known as Jordan's bedstraw, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of the Middle East. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, creeping stems and small, white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its leaves are opposite and often have a hairy texture, contributing to its ability to retain moisture. This variant is of interest to botanists due to its limited distribution and unique ecological niche.
